better_query: What analytical techniques are most effective for assessing the integrity of mRNA payloads within LNP formulations while minimizing sample degradation?

sections.title: Introduction and Background
sections.tldr: mRNA-loaded lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) require sophisticated analytical techniques to assess payload integrity without degrading samples. The challenge lies in maintaining RNA stability during analysis while obtaining accurate characterization data. (LLM Memory)
sections.text:
Messenger RNA (mRNA) therapeutics delivered via lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) have gained significant attention in vaccine and gene therapy applications, especially following the success of COVID-19 vaccines. Assessing the integrity of mRNA payloads within these complex delivery systems presents unique analytical challenges. The fragile nature of RNA molecules makes them susceptible to degradation by ubiquitous ribonucleases (RNases), mechanical stress, and chemical factors during sample preparation and analysis.

Effective analytical techniques must balance the need for detailed characterization with minimal sample perturbation. The enclosed mRNA must be released from the LNP structure for many analyses, yet this process itself can compromise payload integrity. Additionally, the heterogeneous nature of LNP formulations adds complexity to analytical method development. Size, charge, encapsulation efficiency, and sequence integrity all represent critical quality attributes that require assessment.

Traditional analytical approaches have been adapted and new methods developed specifically for mRNA-LNP formulations. These techniques must distinguish between intact and degraded mRNA species while providing information about LNP physical characteristics. The field continues to evolve toward methods that reduce sample manipulation, provide higher resolution, and enable more accurate quantification of intact versus degraded RNA species. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

sections.title: Chromatography-Based Techniques
sections.tldr: Chromatography techniques, particularly ion-pair reversed-phase liquid chromatography (IP-RPLC), are fundamental for assessing mRNA integrity within LNPs. These methods often require LNP disruption using detergents or solvents to liberate the mRNA payload while maintaining its integrity for accurate analysis. (7 sources)
sections.text:
Ion-pair reversed-phase liquid chromatography (IP-RPLC) coupled with UV detection has emerged as a primary method for characterizing mRNA integrity within lipid nanoparticle formulations. This technique enables the separation of negatively charged mRNA molecules based on hydrophobic interactions with the column material, allowing detection of degradation products and shorter fragments that indicate compromised payload integrity. <Paper corpusId="253371061" paperTitle="(Blenke et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>

To effectively analyze mRNA within LNPs, the encapsulated payload must first be released from the nanoparticle structure. Various approaches have been developed to accomplish this extraction while minimizing degradation. Non-ionic detergents are commonly employed to disrupt LNPs and liberate nucleic acid cargos, though these can be detrimental to HPLC columns and may cause signal suppression. Alternative extraction methods include organic solvent/aqueous phase mixtures and phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol solutions. <Paper corpusId="277729479" paperTitle="(Camperi et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="196350748" paperTitle="(Blakney et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>

Recent innovations have focused on optimizing both the extraction process and chromatographic separation. One approach involves using a detergent to disrupt LNPs followed by separation on an octadecyl reversed-phase column with a fast gradient. This method provides reproducible results and efficiently elutes lipids and surfactants using a high organic solvent wash protocol. <Paper corpusId="275992112" paperTitle="(Imiolek et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

Size exclusion chromatography (SEC) offers an alternative or complementary approach to IP-RPLC. An innovative online SEC disruption analysis method has been developed that uses a mobile phase containing alcohol and detergent to universally deformulate LNP samples. This approach enables a rapid 5-minute separation that can serve as a high-throughput platform method. SEC is particularly valuable for separating mRNA aggregates from intact LNPs. <Paper corpusId="275992112" paperTitle="(Imiolek et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="267768573" paperTitle="(Camperi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>

Anion exchange chromatography (AEX) represents another important technique that can be applied to both free and LNP-encapsulated mRNA. Unlike IP-RPLC, AEX has been demonstrated to be more suitable for analyzing longer RNA molecules, such as the 100-nucleotide RNAs used in CRISPR technology. <Paper corpusId="253788302" paperTitle="(Fekete et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="59526403" paperTitle="(Kanavarioti, 2019)" isShortName></Paper>

For comprehensive characterization, liquid chromatography coupled with high-resolution mass spectrometry (LC-HRMS) enables simultaneous analysis of LNP components and impurities, providing detailed information valuable for drug development and quality control. This technique allows researchers to identify and quantify specific lipid components after dissolution from the LNP using solvent-based extraction. <Paper corpusId="253788302" paperTitle="(Fekete et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>

These chromatographic methods not only enable quantification of mRNA payloads but also provide multiattribute analysis capabilities. IP-RPLC can reveal mRNA-lipid adducts, while SEC informs on size variants, thereby reducing analytical workload while maintaining comprehensive characterization. <Paper corpusId="275992112" paperTitle="(Imiolek et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="277729479" paperTitle="(Camperi et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

paper.title: The Storage and In-Use Stability of mRNA Vaccines and Therapeutics: Not A Cold Case

snippets:
A common method to characterize the integrity of the mRNA, i.e., to measure the purity and impurity profile, is IP-RPLC-UV (ion-pair reverse-phase liquid chromatography coupled to UV detection). 76,49 A reversed-phase stationary phase together with a mobile phase containing ion-pair reagent enables retention and separation of the negatively charged mRNA. The separation of fragments with different sizes is based on hydrophobic interaction with the column material. UV detection at 260 nm is employed, as the aforementioned size restrictions preclude the use of MS detection. The IP-RPLC-UV method needs to be optimized to detect the main degradation products, i.e. the shorter fragments, to ensure the method is stability-indicating.

Capillary electrophoresis is an orthogonal method to IP-RPLC-UV, where the separation is based on size. The separation medium is a low viscosity "separation gel", consisting of polymers such as polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) and additives, typically glycerol, as viscosity enhancers. 49,77,78 The polymers form a three-dimensional network that allows the separation based on size. Larger molecules tangle up in the polymer network to a greater extent than smaller fragments and thus migrate slower during the electrophoresis process. The quantification of the fragments and intact mRNA can be either by UV at 260 nm or fluorescence detection

.For the RNA quantification in LNPs, the Quant-it RiboGreen reagent (Thermofisher) characterization is widely used, because it can differentiate between RNA inside and outside the LNP to calculate a percentage encapsulated RNA, which is not straightforward with other methods. 82

paper.title: Current Analytical Strategies for mRNA-Based Therapeutics

snippets: Moreover, IP-RP LC can be used to analyze and quantify mRNA in an LNP formulation, enabling the integrity and purity of the mRNA cargo to be assessed by separating it from other LNP components based on its charge and hydrophobicity, thus providing valuable information for QC in the development of mRNA-based therapies (Lokras et al., 2022)(Imiołek et al., 2025). To this end, a complete extraction of RNA from the carrier is required for quantification of the RNA cargo of nanoparticles. A number of solvents have been employed for extracting RNA from nanoparticles, e.g., non-ionic detergents, organic solvent/aqueous phase mixtures, and phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol (Blenke et al., 2017)(Blakney et al., 2019). Non-ionic detergents are the most widely used extraction reagents due to the effective extraction of nucleic acid cargos from lipid-based nanocarriers. However, detergents are detrimental to HPLC columns, and the LC flow path and can lead to signal suppression

Recently, an innovative detergent-based deformation process and IP-RP separation have been developed to characterize nucleic acid payloads, ranging from the small interfering RNA to Cas9 mRNA [67,68]. To enable direct measurement of double nucleic acid payloads, the use of a deforming SEC mobile phase composed of low levels of sodium dodecyl sulfate and isopropanol is used. This enables intact LNP samples to be injected directly into the LC flow path, where they are dissolved in their individual components [68]. As shown in Figure 6, the IP-RP LC method has sufficient resolution to separate impurities from mRNA adducts and provide information on mRNA quality in addition to quantification, within a 12 min analysis.

paper.title: Inside out: optimization of lipid nanoparticle formulations for exterior complexation and in vivo delivery of saRNA

snippets: Self-amplifying RNA (saRNA) is a promising biotherapeutic tool that has been used as a vaccine against both infectious diseases and cancer. saRNA has been shown to induce protein expression for up to 60 days and elicit immune responses with lower dosing than messenger RNA (mRNA). Because saRNA is a large (~9500 nt), negatively charged molecule, it requires a delivery vehicle for efficient cellular uptake and degradation protection. Lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) have been widely used for RNA formulations, where the prevailing paradigm is to encapsulate RNA within the particle, including the first FDA-approved small-interfering siRNA therapy. Here, we compared LNP formulations with cationic and ionizable lipids with saRNA either on the interior or exterior of the particle. We show that LNPs formulated with cationic lipids protect saRNA from RNAse degradation, even when it is adsorbed to the surface. Furthermore, cationic LNPs deliver saRNA equivalently to particles formulated with saRNA encapsulated in an ionizable lipid particle, both in vitro and in vivo. Finally, we show that cationic and ionizable LNP formulations induce equivalent antibodies against HIV-1 Env gp140 as a model antigen. These studies establish formulating saRNA on the surface of cationic LNPs as an alternative to the paradigm of encapsulating RNA.

paper.title: High-Throughput Quantification and Characterization of Dual Payload mRNA/LNP Cargo via Deformulating Size Exclusion and Ion Pairing Reversed Phase Assays

snippets: Ion pairing reversed phase (IP-RP) and size exclusion chromatography (SEC) are increasingly being used to characterize nucleic acids. Here, we studied their application for payload quantification in formulated LNP drug-like products. Using a detergent to disrupt the LNPs, the liberated payloads can be separated on an octadecyl RP column using a fast gradient. Reproducible results were obtained as lipids, and surfactants were efficiently eluted using a high organic solvent wash protocol. Alternatively, we also established an online SEC disruption analysis of the mRNA/LNPs wherein an alcohol and detergent containing a mobile phase was applied. Such conditions universally deformulated all tested LNP samples, indicating that a 5 min-long SEC separation can be used as a high-throughput platform method.

paper.title: Comprehensive Impurity Profiling of mRNA: Evaluating Current Technologies and Advanced Analytical Techniques

snippets: Several analytical methods are commonly used for mRNA characterization and are employed in quality control (QC) environments to support batch release and stability and assess critical quality attributes (CQAs) at different stages of the drug life cycle, including production and storage. 8,9 Purity is usually assessed by ion-pair reversed-phase liquid chromatography (IP-RPLC) by measuring product-related impurities, such as short mRNA fragments, 10−14 while integrity is usually confirmed by determining mRNA length by capillary gel electrophoresis (CGE). 15,16 As an alternative, Raffaele et al. demonstrated the value of using on-chip capillary electrophoresis to determine the purity and integrity of 2000nucleotide (nt) mRNA in lipid nanoparticle vaccines. 17 ecently, considerable efforts have been made to improve the separation, sensitivity, applicability, and turnaround times of the HPLC-based methods. For example, the choice of the IP-RPLC column, the composition of the mobile phase using an ion-pairing agent, and the column temperature have been studied for short 100-nt RNAs. 10,18 Regarding the analysis of long mRNAs, Kuwayama et al. reported the interest in using an octadecyl-based RPLC column with superwide pores for achieving higher separation. 19 Similarly, an ultrawide pore size exclusion chromatography (SEC) column has been recently introduced for efficient separation of mRNA aggregates and lipid nanoparticles. 20 Additionally, mass photometry (MP) was recently introduced as an interferometric mass spectrometry (MS) methodology capable of measuring the mass and relative abundance of biomolecules in solutions. 21

paper.title: Challenges and emerging trends in liquid chromatography-based analyses of mRNA pharmaceuticals
paper.venue: Journal of Pharmaceutical and Biomedical Analysis

snippets: Separations by anion exchange (AEX), ion-pair reversed phase (IP-RP) or size exclusion (SEC) chromatography are typically applied and are used to detect heterogeneity or check for molecular integrity. AEX and SEC can also be applied to the LNP encapsulated mRNA
Lipids can be dissolved from an LNP using a solvent based extraction so that they can then be individually analyzed by reversed phase chromatography
Oftentimes, a simple dilution with an alcohol is an effective starting point, but some fine tuning may be needed for specialized formulations
LC coupled to HRMS is also important because it allows the simultaneous analysis of LNP components and impurities for a heightened level of information during drug development and/or quality control.

paper.title: HPLC methods for purity evaluation of man-made single-stranded RNAs

snippets: Synthetic RNA oligos exhibit purity decreasing as a function of length, because the efficiency of the total synthesis is the numerical product of the individual step efficiencies, typically below 98%. Analytical methods for RNAs up to the 60 nucleotides (nt) have been reported, but they fall short for purity evaluation of 100nt long, used as single guide RNA (sgRNA) in CRISPR technology, and promoted as pharmaceuticals. In an attempt to exploit a single HPLC method and obtain both identity as well as purity, ion-pair reversed-phase chromatography (IP-RP) at high temperature in the presence of an organic cosolvent is the current analytical strategy. Here we report that IP-RP is less suitable compared to the conventional ion-exchange (IEX) for analysis of 100nt RNAs. We demonstrate the relative stability of RNA in the denaturing/basic IEX mobile phase, lay out a protocol to determine the on-the-column stability of any RNA, and establish the applicability of this method for quality testing of sgRNA, tRNA, and mRNA. Unless well resolving HPLC methods are used for batch-to-batch evaluation of man-made RNAs, process development will remain shortsighted, and observed off-target effects in-vitro or in-vivo may be partially related to low purity and the presence of shorter sequences.

sections.title: Electrophoresis-Based Techniques
sections.tldr: Electrophoresis techniques provide high-resolution analysis of mRNA integrity in LNP formulations, with capillary gel electrophoresis (CGE) and imaged capillary isoelectric focusing (iCIEF) being particularly valuable. These methods enable rapid sample processing while requiring careful optimization of sample preparation protocols to minimize mRNA degradation. (5 sources)
sections.text:
Capillary gel electrophoresis (CGE) has emerged as a crucial technique for determining mRNA length and integrity within LNP formulations. A significant advancement in this area is the development of microchip capillary electrophoresis methods that offer exceptional throughput. The LabChip GXII Touch instrument enables analysis in approximately 70 seconds per sample, processing a full 96-well plate in just 2.5 hours, making it particularly valuable for vaccine development. Sample preparation for this method requires careful optimization, with high formamide concentrations (>80% v/v) and heating at 70°C for 10 minutes to ensure complete mRNA denaturation. <Paper corpusId="244477586" paperTitle="(Raffaele et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

When comparing sample preparation methods for CGE analysis, significant differences in performance have been observed. Recent research has systematically evaluated two common disruption protocols: detergent treatment (Triton X-100) and precipitation by organic solvent (isopropanol). The findings revealed that detergent treatment significantly impacts fluorescence intensity of the main peak, even at low concentrations, resulting in lower integrity measurements and increased variability. In contrast, isopropanol precipitation demonstrates superior performance by removing non-precipitating buffer components, thereby improving assay sensitivity. Optimal conditions for CGE with laser-induced fluorescence (CGE-LIF) include isopropanol precipitation, high urea concentrations, no formamide as a sample diluent, and high concentrations of fluorescent dye. <Paper corpusId="277276414" paperTitle="(Tran et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

Imaged capillary isoelectric focusing (iCIEF) represents another powerful electrophoretic technique specifically adapted for mRNA-LNP analysis. Two distinct iCIEF methods have been developed, each with complementary strengths. Method A employs 9 M urea as an additive, generating two broad, jagged peaks whose shape changes substantially when samples are stressed, providing detailed stability information. Interestingly, the peak pattern exhibits fine structure that may correlate to different numbers of mRNA molecules within individual LNPs. Method B uses a combination of 5.5 M urea and 2 M N-ethylurea for LNP separation, offering high repeatability of isoelectric point values (<0.5%). Both methods demonstrate well-repeatable peak areas (2-8% relative standard deviation) that correlate linearly with mRNA content. <Paper corpusId="251808672" paperTitle="(Krebs et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>

The value of iCIEF extends beyond basic characterization to process monitoring and formulation development. The technique effectively differentiates the isoelectric points of LNPs containing different ionizable lipids, aiding in LNP identity verification during manufacturing. As a quantitative method, iCIEF provides insights into LNP stability under various conditions, including different storage temperatures, freeze-thaw cycles, and lipid compositions, making it capable of detecting batch-to-batch variability. <Paper corpusId="276512626" paperTitle="(Ghizzani et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

Both CGE and iCIEF complement chromatography-based techniques like ion-pair reversed-phase liquid chromatography (IP-RPLC). While IP-RPLC excels at assessing mRNA purity by measuring product-related impurities such as short fragments, CGE is particularly well-suited for confirming integrity by determining precise mRNA length. The combined use of these orthogonal techniques provides comprehensive characterization of critical quality attributes throughout the drug lifecycle, including production and storage phases. <Paper corpusId="267768573" paperTitle="(Camperi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>

paper.title: Development of a microchip capillary electrophoresis method for determination of the purity and integrity of mRNA in lipid nanoparticle vaccines

snippets: We have developed a quick and reproducible microchip CE method for evaluating the % purity and % integrity of mRNA in mRNA-LNP vaccine samples. The method utilizes the LabChip GXII Touch instrument from Perkin Elmer, which allows for high-throughput sample analysis due to the short run time of ∼ 70 s per sample and can run a 96-well plate in approximately 2.5 h. These advantages are especially useful for vaccine development and the method required minimal changes for optimization of its use for additional mRNA vaccine products. Assay development was optimized mostly with respect to sample preparation since the instrument and separation kit are fixed from Perkin Elmer. Sample treatment was optimized by the addition of high formamide concentration (>80% v/v) and heating at 70°C for 10 min to ensure mRNA was fully denatured.

paper.title: A Comprehensive Evaluation of Analytical Method Parameters Critical to the Reliable Assessment of Therapeutic mRNA Integrity by Capillary Gel Electrophoresis

snippets: Currently, capillary gel electrophoresis with laser‐induced fluorescence (CGE‐LIF) and ion‐pair reversed‐phase liquid chromatography (IP‐RPLC) are techniques of choice for mRNA integrity analysis

To address the knowledge gaps of CGE-LIF and IP-RPLC method performance for mRNA-LNPs, we used a large commercial mRNA-LNP product (∼4200 b) to systematically evaluate critical method parameters for CGE-LIF and compared them to IP-RPLC

Given the importance of disruption in sample preparation, two common disruption protocols were evaluated. These were mRNA-LNP treatment with detergent (Triton X-100) and precipitation by organic solvent (isopropanol)
After mRNA-LNP samples were disrupted by Triton X-100, fluorescence intensity of the main peak was significantly impacted, even at low detergent concentrations
which also resulted in lower integrity measurements and increased variability compared to isopropanol treatment
suggesting that isopropanol precipitation removal of non-precipitating buffer components improves assay sensitivity

We found that optimal conditions for CGE‐LIF assay sensitivity, variability, and resolution included sample precipitation by isopropanol, high urea concentrations, no formamide as a sample diluent, and high concentrations of dye.

paper.title: Two quality and stability indicating imaged CIEF methods for mRNA vaccines

snippets: Two iCIEF methods have been developed, both having their strengths, and united providing many insights into the quality and stability of mRNA vaccines. The highly repeatable methods offer a lot of very valuable information about the preparation, and at the same time they are flexible to optimize them for various kinds of loaded LNPs. Method A, in which 9 M urea was used as an additive, shows two broad and jagged peaks in which the peak shape changes substantially when stress is added to the samples, and therefore detailed information can be derived about stability. Furthermore, the peak pattern exhibits an interesting fine structure, possibly due to different numbers of mRNA molecules within the individual LNPs. The peak area of the sum of both peaks, with RSDs from 2% to 8% when measured in triplicate, very well correlates linearly with the mRNA content and also apparently depends on the size of the LNPs, as was shown by the additional examinations of the stressed samples with the Zetasizer. In method B, a combination of 5.5 M urea and 2 M N-ethylurea was used for LNP separation by iCIEF. This method is characterized by a high repeatability of the pI value (<0.5%). Again, the well repeatable peak area (2%-7%) correlates linearly with the mRNA content, and added stress is evident by the change in pI and peak area.

paper.title: Exploring imaged capillary isoelectric focusing parameters for enhanced charge variants quality control

snippets: In addition, icIEF can be employed to assess the surface charge of lipid nanoparticle (LNP)-based mRNA vaccines (Loughney et al., 2019(Loughney et al., , 2602(Loughney et al., -2609)). This technique is capable of differentiating the pI of LNPs that contain one or more types of ionizable lipids, aiding in the verification of LNP identity during manufacturing processes. As a quantitative method, icIEF also provides insights into the stability of LNPs, making it applicable for both process optimization and formulation development of mRNA vaccines

Two distinct icIEF approaches have been developed, as reported in the literature, to evaluate the quality and stability of mRNA vaccines, particularly those encapsulated in LNPs. These methods are effective for characterising the stability of mRNA-loaded LNPs under different conditions, such as varied storage temperatures, freeze-thaw cycles, and lipid compositions, and are capable of detecting batch-to-batch variability. Overall, icIEF analysis has proven to be highly suitable for characterising mRNA vaccines.

paper.title: Comprehensive Impurity Profiling of mRNA: Evaluating Current Technologies and Advanced Analytical Techniques

snippets: Several analytical methods are commonly used for mRNA characterization and are employed in quality control (QC) environments to support batch release and stability and assess critical quality attributes (CQAs) at different stages of the drug life cycle, including production and storage. 8,9 Purity is usually assessed by ion-pair reversed-phase liquid chromatography (IP-RPLC) by measuring product-related impurities, such as short mRNA fragments, 10−14 while integrity is usually confirmed by determining mRNA length by capillary gel electrophoresis (CGE). 15,16 As an alternative, Raffaele et al. demonstrated the value of using on-chip capillary electrophoresis to determine the purity and integrity of 2000nucleotide (nt) mRNA in lipid nanoparticle vaccines. 17 ecently, considerable efforts have been made to improve the separation, sensitivity, applicability, and turnaround times of the HPLC-based methods. For example, the choice of the IP-RPLC column, the composition of the mobile phase using an ion-pairing agent, and the column temperature have been studied for short 100-nt RNAs. 10,18 Regarding the analysis of long mRNAs, Kuwayama et al. reported the interest in using an octadecyl-based RPLC column with superwide pores for achieving higher separation. 19 Similarly, an ultrawide pore size exclusion chromatography (SEC) column has been recently introduced for efficient separation of mRNA aggregates and lipid nanoparticles. 20 Additionally, mass photometry (MP) was recently introduced as an interferometric mass spectrometry (MS) methodology capable of measuring the mass and relative abundance of biomolecules in solutions. 21

sections.title: Sample Preparation Methods to Minimize Degradation
sections.tldr: Effective sample preparation is crucial for maintaining mRNA integrity during analytical testing of LNP formulations, with isopropanol precipitation proving superior to detergent-based methods. Minimizing sample manipulation, controlling storage conditions, and optimizing denaturing conditions are essential strategies for preventing mRNA degradation during analysis. (4 sources)
sections.text:
Extracting mRNA from lipid nanoparticles while preserving its integrity represents a critical step in analytical workflows. Several approaches have been developed for this purpose, including non-ionic detergents, organic solvent/aqueous phase mixtures, and phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol solutions. <Paper corpusId="277729479" paperTitle="(Camperi et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> When comparing these methods, systematic evaluations have revealed significant performance differences. For example, Triton X-100 detergent treatment, even at low concentrations, negatively impacts fluorescence intensity during capillary gel electrophoresis with laser-induced fluorescence (CGE-LIF), resulting in lower integrity measurements and increased variability. <Paper corpusId="277276414" paperTitle="(Tran et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

In contrast, isopropanol precipitation has emerged as a superior method for sample preparation. This approach effectively removes non-precipitating buffer components, thereby improving assay sensitivity for techniques like CGE-LIF. <Paper corpusId="277276414" paperTitle="(Tran et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> Research has established that optimal conditions for CGE-LIF analysis include sample precipitation by isopropanol, high urea concentrations, no formamide as a sample diluent, and high concentrations of fluorescent dye. <Paper corpusId="277276414" paperTitle="(Tran et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

For microchip capillary electrophoresis methods utilizing instruments like the LabChip GXII Touch, sample treatment optimization is essential for accurate results. Specific denaturing conditions, including high formamide concentration (>80% v/v) and heating at 70°C for 10 minutes, ensure complete mRNA denaturation for proper analysis. <Paper corpusId="244477586" paperTitle="(Raffaele et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

Beyond extraction methods, several strategies help minimize degradation throughout the analytical workflow. Properly formulated mRNA-LNPs contain PEG-lipids to prevent aggregation and provide sufficient encapsulation efficiency to protect mRNA from external degradation factors. Sample manipulation should be minimized during assay execution and shipping, with samples stored under frozen or refrigerated conditions. When shipping liquid samples, minimal headspace helps reduce potential degradation. <Paper corpusId="277314962" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

For ion-pair reversed-phase liquid chromatography (IP-RPLC), innovative approaches combine detergent-based deformation with chromatographic separation. One method employs a deforming size exclusion chromatography mobile phase containing low levels of sodium dodecyl sulfate and isopropanol, allowing intact LNP samples to be injected directly into the LC flow path where they are dissolved into individual components. <Paper corpusId="277729479" paperTitle="(Camperi et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> This approach maintains sufficient resolution to separate impurities from mRNA adducts while providing quality information within a 12-minute analysis. <Paper corpusId="277729479" paperTitle="(Camperi et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

A critical consideration when using detergents for extraction is their potential detrimental effect on HPLC columns and the LC flow path, as well as possible signal suppression. <Paper corpusId="277729479" paperTitle="(Camperi et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> These factors must be carefully balanced against the extraction efficiency to ensure accurate analytical results while maintaining mRNA integrity throughout the preparation and analysis process.

paper.title: Current Analytical Strategies for mRNA-Based Therapeutics

To this end, a complete extraction of RNA from the carrier is required for quantification of the RNA cargo of nanoparticles. A number of solvents have been employed for extracting RNA from nanoparticles, e.g., non-ionic detergents, organic solvent/aqueous phase mixtures, and phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol (Blenke et al., 2017)(Blakney et al., 2019). Non-ionic detergents are the most widely used extraction reagents due to the effective extraction of nucleic acid cargos from lipid-based nanocarriers. However, detergents are detrimental to HPLC columns, and the LC flow path and can lead to signal suppression

Recently, an innovative detergent-based deformation process and IP-RP separation have been developed to characterize nucleic acid payloads, ranging from the small interfering RNA to Cas9 mRNA [67,68]. To enable direct measurement of double nucleic acid payloads, the use of a deforming SEC mobile phase composed of low levels of sodium dodecyl sulfate and isopropanol is used. This enables intact LNP samples to be injected directly into the LC flow path, where they are dissolved in their individual components [68]. As shown in Figure 6, the IP-RP LC method has sufficient resolution to separate impurities from mRNA adducts and provide information on mRNA quality in addition to quantification, within a 12 min analysis.

To address the knowledge gaps of CGE-LIF and IP-RPLC method performance for mRNA-LNPs, we used a large commercial mRNA-LNP product (∼4200 b) to systematically evaluate critical method parameters for CGE-LIF and compared them to IP-RPLC

Given the importance of disruption in sample preparation, two common disruption protocols were evaluated. These were mRNA-LNP treatment with detergent (Triton X-100) and precipitation by organic solvent (isopropanol)

which also resulted in lower integrity measurements and increased variability compared to isopropanol treatment
suggesting that isopropanol precipitation removal of non-precipitating buffer components improves assay sensitivity

snippets: We have developed a quick and reproducible microchip CE method for evaluating the % purity and % integrity of mRNA in mRNA-LNP vaccine samples. The method utilizes the LabChip GXII Touch instrument from Perkin Elmer, which allows for high-throughput sample analysis due to the short run time of ∼ 70 s per sample and can run a 96-well plate in approximately 2.5 h. These advantages are especially useful for vaccine development and the method required minimal changes for optimization of its use for additional mRNA vaccine products. Assay development was optimized mostly with respect to sample preparation since the instrument and separation kit are fixed from Perkin Elmer. Sample treatment was optimized by the addition of high formamide concentration (>80% v/v) and heating at 70°C for 10 min to ensure mRNA was fully denatured.

paper.title: A novel in-vitro expression assay by LC/MS/MS enables multi-antigen mRNA vaccine characterization

snippets: All mRNA-LNP formulations contained PEG-lipids to avoid LNP aggregation and provided sufficient encapsulation efficiency to mitigate mRNA degradation by external factors. Additionally, degradation was prevented by minimizing sample manipulation during assay execution and sample shipment. Samples were stored under frozen or refrigerated conditions and liquid samples were shipped with minimal headspace to reduce potential sample degradation.

sections.title: Specialized Analytical Techniques
sections.tldr: Beyond standard chromatography and electrophoresis methods, specialized techniques like modified RiboGreen assays, analytical ultracentrifugation, and cell-free protein expression systems offer unique capabilities for assessing mRNA-LNP integrity with minimal sample manipulation. (7 sources)
sections.text:
- **Dynamic Light Scattering (DLS)** provides rapid size distribution analysis of LNP formulations without requiring sample disruption, offering a non-destructive approach to characterize particle size profiles. <Paper corpusId="258370274" paperTitle="(Niazi, 2023)" isShortName></Paper>

- **Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM)** enables direct visualization of LNP morphology and structure, providing qualitative insights into particle shape and potential aggregation that complement quantitative size measurements. <Paper corpusId="258370274" paperTitle="(Niazi, 2023)" isShortName></Paper>

- **Modified RiboGreen Assay** represents the most widely used method for determining encapsulation efficiency of LNP formulations. This fluorescence-based technique first measures unencapsulated RNA in intact LNPs, then uses a detergent (typically Triton X-100) to disrupt particles and quantify total RNA. Encapsulation efficiency is calculated as the ratio of encapsulated RNA (determined by subtraction) to total RNA. <Paper corpusId="267318738" paperTitle="(Schober et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="6328739" paperTitle="(Jones et al., 1998)" isShortName></Paper>

- **Analytical Ultracentrifugation (AUC)** offers several distinct advantages for mRNA-LNP characterization. Density contrast AUC can determine mRNA copy numbers within individual LNPs, revealing distributions typically ranging from 1-10 mRNA copies per particle. <Paper corpusId="259110832" paperTitle="(Bepperling et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> As a robust method for measuring particle size distribution, AUC requires minimal sample preparation (only dilution), avoiding potential biases introduced by ultrafiltration, RNA extraction, or particle disruption steps. Its ability to specifically detect RNA signals (using UV detection at 260 nm) allows characterization in physiologically relevant media. <Paper corpusId="270020439" paperTitle="(Guerrini et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="244484823" paperTitle="(Valderrama et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

- **Cell-Free Protein Expression Systems** provide functional assessment of mRNA integrity by evaluating expression levels following extraction from LNPs. This approach complements structural analysis techniques by directly measuring the functional capacity of the mRNA payload. <Paper corpusId="278107072" paperTitle="(Forrester et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

- **HPLC with Evaporative Light Scattering Detection (HPLC-ELSD)** specifically assesses lipid integrity and ensures high lipid recovery in LNP formulations, providing complementary data to techniques focused on mRNA analysis. <Paper corpusId="278107072" paperTitle="(Forrester et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

paper.title: RNA Therapeutics: A Healthcare Paradigm Shift

snippets: Various analytical techniques, such as dynamic light scattering (DLS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and reverse-phase high-performance liquid chromatography (RP-HPLC), may be used to characterize the size, morphology, and encapsulation efficiency of LNPs.

paper.title: A careful look at lipid nanoparticle characterization: analysis of benchmark formulations for encapsulation of RNA cargo size gradient

snippets: While there are a handful of methods to characterize encapsulation efficiency of an LNP formulation for its cargo, modified RiboGreen assay is by far the most common [25][26][27][28][29][30]. RiboGreen is a dye developed for quantitation of RNA in which fluorescence is produced upon nucleic acid binding 31. For determination of encapsulation efficiency in LNPs, RiboGreen is first added to the sample with LNPs intact to measure the unencapsulated RNA concentration. A detergent solution (e.g. Triton X-100) is then added to disrupt the nanoparticles, releasing encapsulated RNA, and the total amount of RNA in the sample is calculated from RiboGreen fluorescence. Encapsulated RNA is calculated by subtracting unencapsulated RNA from total RNA and encapsulation efficiency is then taken as the ratio of encapsulated RNA to total RNA in the sample.

paper.title: RNA quantitation by fluorescence-based solution assay: RiboGreen reagent characterization.

snippets: We describe the development of a sensitive fluorescence-based solution assay for RNA using a new dye, RiboGreen RNA quantitation reagent. RiboGreen reagent exhibits >1000-fold fluorescence enhancement and high quantum yield (0.65) upon binding nucleic acids, with excitation and emission maxima near those of fluorescein. Unbound dye is essentially nonfluorescent and has a large extinction coefficient (67,000 cm-1 M-1). The RiboGreen assay allows detection of as little as 1.0 ng/ml RNA in a standard fluorometer, filter fluorometer, or fluorescence microplate reader-surpassing the sensitivity achieved with ethidium bromide by 200-fold. The linear quantitation range for RiboGreen reagent extends over three orders of magnitude in RNA concentration. Using 750 nM RiboGreen reagent, we quantitated 20 ng/ml to 1.0 microg/ml RNA. By diluting the reagent to 75 nM, we could quantitate 1.0 to 50 ng/ml RNA. Both assay ranges exhibited linear fluorescence increases versus RNA concentration (r2 = 0.999). Assay linearity was maintained in the presence of salts, protein, urea, ethanol, chloroform, agarose, and some detergents. Several different RNA types yielded similar signal intensities and detection sensitivities. The assay is easy to use, rapid, and readily adaptable for automation.

paper.title: Determination of mRNA copy number in degradable lipid nanoparticles via density contrast analytical ultracentrifugation

snippets: Density contrast AUC offers a rapid and simple assay for the determination of mRNA copy numbers for lipid nanoparticle formulations. We have determined a discrete distribution ranging from 1 to 10 mRNA copies with an average of 5 copies per particle for our LNP formulation. However, potential users should keep two limitations in mind. First, this assay cannot distinguish between full length and degraded mRNA and thus confirm the integrity of the encapsulated nucleic acid. An LNP with 5 mRNA copies will have the same density as a particle with 10 half copies. This must be monitored by other assays such as (capillary) gel electrophoresis during drug substance/drug product characterization.

paper.title: Analytical Ultracentrifugation to Assess the Quality of LNP-mRNA Therapeutics

snippets: AUC is a robust method for measuring the particle size distribution of LNP-mRNA formulations, underpinned by extensive scientific literature (Zhao et al., 2013)(Mehn et al., 2018)(Schuck, 2013) and existing protocols (Valderrama et al., 2021)(Schuck, 2000)

The technique requires a relatively low amount of sample and no sample preparation (apart from dilution step). This is extremely important as it avoids any potential bias in the results that could be introduced by ultrafiltration steps, RNA extraction, or particle disruption that are needed when using other analytical techniques. The simplicity of the sample preparation and the specific detection of the signal from the RNA molecule (using the UV detector at 260 nm) also allow the characterization of LNP-mRNA in physiologically relevant media [34].

paper.title: Reincarnation of the Analytical Ultracentrifuge: Emerging Opportunities for Nanomedicine.

snippets: The analytical ultracentrifuge (AUC) and the modern field of analytical ultracentrifugation found its inception approximately a century ago. We highlight the scope of its major experimental opportunities as a transport-based method, contemporary and up-and-coming investigation potential for polymers, polymer-drug conjugates, polymer assemblies, as well as medical nanoparticles. Special focus lies on molar mass estimates of unimeric polymeric species, self-assemblies in solution, and (co)localization of multicomponent systems in solution alongside the material-biofluid interactions. We close with present challenges and incentives for future research.

paper.title: Low-Cost Microfluidic Mixers: Are They up to the Task?

snippets: To achieve this, in addition to testing in vitro and in vivo efficacy, a cell-free protein expression system was employed to evaluate mRNA expression levels following extraction from LNPs, while HPLC-ELSD analysis was used to assess lipid integrity and ensure high lipid recovery (Figure 4).

sections.title: Comparative Effectiveness of Techniques
sections.tldr: Each analytical technique for assessing mRNA-LNP integrity offers distinct advantages and limitations, with no single method providing comprehensive characterization. An integrated approach combining orthogonal methods like IP-RPLC, CGE, and specialized techniques like AUC yields the most complete assessment of payload integrity. (6 sources)
sections.text:
When comparing the effectiveness of analytical techniques for assessing mRNA integrity in LNP formulations, it becomes clear that different methods offer complementary strengths addressing specific quality attributes. Ion-pair reversed-phase liquid chromatography (IP-RPLC) coupled with UV detection serves as a primary method for purity assessment by measuring product-related impurities, particularly shorter mRNA fragments. <Paper corpusId="253371061" paperTitle="(Blenke et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> This technique has become a cornerstone of mRNA-LNP analysis due to its ability to separate fragments based on hydrophobic interactions with the column material. However, research has shown that IP-RPLC becomes less effective as RNA length increases, with anion exchange chromatography (IEX) demonstrating superior performance for longer RNAs, such as the 100-nucleotide RNAs used in CRISPR technology. <Paper corpusId="253371061" paperTitle="(Blenke et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="59526403" paperTitle="(Kanavarioti, 2019)" isShortName></Paper>

Capillary gel electrophoresis (CGE) represents an orthogonal method to IP-RPLC, where separation is based primarily on molecular size rather than hydrophobic interactions. <Paper corpusId="253371061" paperTitle="(Blenke et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper> While IP-RPLC excels at purity assessment, CGE is particularly effective for confirming integrity by precisely determining mRNA length. <Paper corpusId="267768573" paperTitle="(Camperi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> Recent comparative studies between CGE-LIF and IP-RPLC for mRNA-LNP analysis have revealed important differences in their performance characteristics, particularly regarding sample preparation methods. When comparing detergent treatment (Triton X-100) versus isopropanol precipitation for sample disruption, research shows that detergent treatment significantly impacts fluorescence intensity and results in lower integrity measurements with increased variability. In contrast, isopropanol precipitation demonstrates superior performance by improving assay sensitivity. <Paper corpusId="277276414" paperTitle="(Tran et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

Among specialized techniques, analytical ultracentrifugation (AUC) offers unique advantages for assessing LNP-mRNA formulations. AUC requires minimal sample preparation—only dilution—avoiding potential biases introduced by ultrafiltration, RNA extraction, or particle disruption steps necessary for other techniques. The ability to specifically detect RNA signals using UV detection at 260 nm allows characterization in physiologically relevant media, providing insights that may be more representative of in vivo conditions. <Paper corpusId="270020439" paperTitle="(Guerrini et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="244484823" paperTitle="(Valderrama et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>

For comprehensive characterization of mRNA-LNP formulations, multiple analytical methods are typically employed in quality control environments to support batch release and stability testing throughout the drug lifecycle. <Paper corpusId="267768573" paperTitle="(Camperi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> The RiboGreen assay remains widely used specifically for determining encapsulation efficiency, providing complementary information to structural analysis techniques like IP-RPLC and CGE. <Paper corpusId="253371061" paperTitle="(Blenke et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>

Recent technological advancements have focused on improving separation, sensitivity, applicability, and turnaround times of these analytical methods. Innovations include the development of octadecyl-based RPLC columns with superwide pores for achieving higher separation of long mRNAs and ultrawide pore size exclusion chromatography columns for efficient separation of mRNA aggregates from lipid nanoparticles. <Paper corpusId="267768573" paperTitle="(Camperi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> These improvements directly address key limitations of traditional methods when applied to increasingly complex mRNA-LNP formulations.

When selecting analytical techniques for a specific application, considerations should include the mRNA length, required resolution, sample preparation constraints, and the specific quality attributes being assessed. An integrated approach utilizing multiple orthogonal methods provides the most comprehensive characterization of mRNA integrity within LNP formulations. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

paper.title: The Storage and In-Use Stability of mRNA Vaccines and Therapeutics: Not A Cold Case

snippets:
A common method to characterize the integrity of the mRNA, i.e., to measure the purity and impurity profile, is IP-RPLC-UV (ion-pair reverse-phase liquid chromatography coupled to UV detection). 76,49 A reversed-phase stationary phase together with a mobile phase containing ion-pair reagent enables retention and separation of the negatively charged mRNA. The separation of fragments with different sizes is based on hydrophobic interaction with the column material. UV detection at 260 nm is employed, as the aforementioned size restrictions preclude the use of MS detection. The IP-RPLC-UV method needs to be optimized to detect the main degradation products, i.e. the shorter fragments, to ensure the method is stability-indicating.

Capillary electrophoresis is an orthogonal method to IP-RPLC-UV, where the separation is based on size. The separation medium is a low viscosity "separation gel", consisting of polymers such as polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) and additives, typically glycerol, as viscosity enhancers. 49,77,78 The polymers form a three-dimensional network that allows the separation based on size. Larger molecules tangle up in the polymer network to a greater extent than smaller fragments and thus migrate slower during the electrophoresis process. The quantification of the fragments and intact mRNA can be either by UV at 260 nm or fluorescence detection

.For the RNA quantification in LNPs, the Quant-it RiboGreen reagent (Thermofisher) characterization is widely used, because it can differentiate between RNA inside and outside the LNP to calculate a percentage encapsulated RNA, which is not straightforward with other methods. 82

paper.title: HPLC methods for purity evaluation of man-made single-stranded RNAs

snippets: Synthetic RNA oligos exhibit purity decreasing as a function of length, because the efficiency of the total synthesis is the numerical product of the individual step efficiencies, typically below 98%. Analytical methods for RNAs up to the 60 nucleotides (nt) have been reported, but they fall short for purity evaluation of 100nt long, used as single guide RNA (sgRNA) in CRISPR technology, and promoted as pharmaceuticals. In an attempt to exploit a single HPLC method and obtain both identity as well as purity, ion-pair reversed-phase chromatography (IP-RP) at high temperature in the presence of an organic cosolvent is the current analytical strategy. Here we report that IP-RP is less suitable compared to the conventional ion-exchange (IEX) for analysis of 100nt RNAs. We demonstrate the relative stability of RNA in the denaturing/basic IEX mobile phase, lay out a protocol to determine the on-the-column stability of any RNA, and establish the applicability of this method for quality testing of sgRNA, tRNA, and mRNA. Unless well resolving HPLC methods are used for batch-to-batch evaluation of man-made RNAs, process development will remain shortsighted, and observed off-target effects in-vitro or in-vivo may be partially related to low purity and the presence of shorter sequences.

paper.title: Comprehensive Impurity Profiling of mRNA: Evaluating Current Technologies and Advanced Analytical Techniques

snippets: Several analytical methods are commonly used for mRNA characterization and are employed in quality control (QC) environments to support batch release and stability and assess critical quality attributes (CQAs) at different stages of the drug life cycle, including production and storage. 8,9 Purity is usually assessed by ion-pair reversed-phase liquid chromatography (IP-RPLC) by measuring product-related impurities, such as short mRNA fragments, 10−14 while integrity is usually confirmed by determining mRNA length by capillary gel electrophoresis (CGE). 15,16 As an alternative, Raffaele et al. demonstrated the value of using on-chip capillary electrophoresis to determine the purity and integrity of 2000nucleotide (nt) mRNA in lipid nanoparticle vaccines. 17 ecently, considerable efforts have been made to improve the separation, sensitivity, applicability, and turnaround times of the HPLC-based methods. For example, the choice of the IP-RPLC column, the composition of the mobile phase using an ion-pairing agent, and the column temperature have been studied for short 100-nt RNAs. 10,18 Regarding the analysis of long mRNAs, Kuwayama et al. reported the interest in using an octadecyl-based RPLC column with superwide pores for achieving higher separation. 19 Similarly, an ultrawide pore size exclusion chromatography (SEC) column has been recently introduced for efficient separation of mRNA aggregates and lipid nanoparticles. 20 Additionally, mass photometry (MP) was recently introduced as an interferometric mass spectrometry (MS) methodology capable of measuring the mass and relative abundance of biomolecules in solutions. 21

paper.title: A Comprehensive Evaluation of Analytical Method Parameters Critical to the Reliable Assessment of Therapeutic mRNA Integrity by Capillary Gel Electrophoresis

snippets: Currently, capillary gel electrophoresis with laser‐induced fluorescence (CGE‐LIF) and ion‐pair reversed‐phase liquid chromatography (IP‐RPLC) are techniques of choice for mRNA integrity analysis

To address the knowledge gaps of CGE-LIF and IP-RPLC method performance for mRNA-LNPs, we used a large commercial mRNA-LNP product (∼4200 b) to systematically evaluate critical method parameters for CGE-LIF and compared them to IP-RPLC

Given the importance of disruption in sample preparation, two common disruption protocols were evaluated. These were mRNA-LNP treatment with detergent (Triton X-100) and precipitation by organic solvent (isopropanol)
After mRNA-LNP samples were disrupted by Triton X-100, fluorescence intensity of the main peak was significantly impacted, even at low detergent concentrations
which also resulted in lower integrity measurements and increased variability compared to isopropanol treatment
suggesting that isopropanol precipitation removal of non-precipitating buffer components improves assay sensitivity

We found that optimal conditions for CGE‐LIF assay sensitivity, variability, and resolution included sample precipitation by isopropanol, high urea concentrations, no formamide as a sample diluent, and high concentrations of dye.

paper.title: Analytical Ultracentrifugation to Assess the Quality of LNP-mRNA Therapeutics

snippets: AUC is a robust method for measuring the particle size distribution of LNP-mRNA formulations, underpinned by extensive scientific literature (Zhao et al., 2013)(Mehn et al., 2018)(Schuck, 2013) and existing protocols (Valderrama et al., 2021)(Schuck, 2000)

The technique requires a relatively low amount of sample and no sample preparation (apart from dilution step). This is extremely important as it avoids any potential bias in the results that could be introduced by ultrafiltration steps, RNA extraction, or particle disruption that are needed when using other analytical techniques. The simplicity of the sample preparation and the specific detection of the signal from the RNA molecule (using the UV detector at 260 nm) also allow the characterization of LNP-mRNA in physiologically relevant media [34].

snippets: The analytical ultracentrifuge (AUC) and the modern field of analytical ultracentrifugation found its inception approximately a century ago. We highlight the scope of its major experimental opportunities as a transport-based method, contemporary and up-and-coming investigation potential for polymers, polymer-drug conjugates, polymer assemblies, as well as medical nanoparticles. Special focus lies on molar mass estimates of unimeric polymeric species, self-assemblies in solution, and (co)localization of multicomponent systems in solution alongside the material-biofluid interactions. We close with present challenges and incentives for future research.
